Posts.Content: May 7, 2008 11:51AM Lynn12 wrote: Hi dpt, I don't know much about itching breasts..hopefully it will be something other than cancer! I also have a PPO and I must say that I am thrilled with what they have paid.  I've had 3 surgeries (one of which had a 5 day hospital stay), 4 months of chemo, 30 radiation treatments, MRI'S, scans, blood work...the works.  My insurance company has been billed over $200,000 since 11/06 and I've had to pay under $1,000.  Most of it was the $250 per surgery.  They haven't denied one thing.  I think because you have a PPO, you should feel comfortable with your insurance. Best of luck to you! Lynn

Posts.Content: May 8, 2008 09:59PM Lynn12 wrote: I had severe back pain last summer. I had been diagnosed with herniated disk about 5 years ago, however the pain went away, then late summer I could hardly get out of bed. I finished chemo in May and radiation in July.  I told my Onc and he sent me for an MRI. The result was herniated disk and arthritis, no cancer.  I think it got all irritated from laying on the radiation table for 6 weeks.  After the MRI came back, I went to my PCP who then sent me to a spine Dr.  I had a steriod injection which didn't really work.  He also said there is another treatment for arthritis, but I just can't get myself to go through with it since I am still in reconstruction surgeries.  Hopefully it's not cancer, but do get it checked out! best of luck!

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2008 04:44PM Lynn12 wrote: I don't think you get 'addicted' to Ativan, more like 'dependant' on it.  I was dx over a year ago and was prescribed Ativan to help me sleep and calm my racing mind, then during chemo to help with the nausea.  Now I'm on tamoxifen, have hot flashes and Ativan helps me sleep at night.  Like bandteacher, I don't see anything wrong with taking it. I take tamoxifen to help keep cancer away, I take Ativan to help me sleep so I can live my life as close to normal as I can.  My Onc has no problem with me taking it to help me sleep. Rest is very important!

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2008 01:09PM Lynn12 wrote: Hi Kasey, I went to Dana Farber for a 2nd opinion after I was diagnosed and had surgery in late 2006.  I was very impressed with the Oncologist that saw me.  He was going to be VERY aggressive with my treatment.  However he did agree with what my local Onc's treatment plan, so I stayed local instead of driving the 2 hours to get to DF.  They are also very involved in clinical trials. Lynn

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2007 01:12PM Lynn12 wrote: Hello Jan. 08 girls, I'm joining my Jan. 07 sisters in offering you all our love and support.  It's so hard to believe it's been a year since we entered the chemo journey!  I had 6 rounds of TC three weeks apart.  Started 1/19/07, finished 5/8/07.  Like others said, take the anti-nausea. I started out with Compazine, then Zofran, ended up with Emend my last 2 tx.  Wish I had it from the beginning, so ask for it if you can!  Listen to your body, rest, rest, rest! Wishing you all the best!  You can do it, it'll be done before you know it! hugs, Lynn

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2008 05:21PM Lynn12 wrote: I had my port put in by a radiologist at the hospital. My Onc said this is being done more often than having a surgeon do it. I had the twilight anethesia so I was pretty loopy and didn't really care what was going on (I talked to the poor nurses about football..lol).  All in all, it was pretty easy. I was sore for a few days after, but not a big deal.
